answer_html: \(\frac{1}{f(2)}f'(2)\cdot 2=-\frac{10}{3}.\) Hence, the slope of the tangent line at \(x=1\) is equal to \(-10/3.\)
answer_latex:
$\frac{1}{f(2)}f'(2)\cdot 2=-\frac{10}{3}.$ 
Hence, the slope of the tangent line at $x=1$ is equal to $-10/3.$
hints_html:
The slope of the graph at \(x=1\) is simply the derivative, \(dy/dx,\) evaluated when \(x=1.\)

Use the chain rule to find the derivative, \(dy/dx.\)
hints_latex:
The slope of the graph at $x=1$ is simply the derivative, $dy/dx,$
evaluated when $x=1.$
Use the chain rule to find the derivative, $dy/dx.$
hints_raw:
The slope of the graph at <math>x=1 </math> is simply the derivative, <math>dy/dx, </math> evaluated when <math> x=1.</math>
Use the chain rule to find the derivative, <math> dy/dx.</math>
question: 1 (f)
sols_html:
By the chain rule,

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{1}{f(2x)}f'(2x)\cdot 2\end{aligned}\]

When \(x=1,\) this is equal to

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{f(2)}f'(2)\cdot 2 =\frac{1}{3} (-5)\cdot 2 = -\frac{10}{3}.\end{aligned}\]

Hence, the slope of the tangent line at \(x=1\) is equal to \(-10/3.\)
sols_raw:
By the chain rule,
:<math>\frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{1}{f(2x)}f'(2x)\cdot 2 </math>
When <math>x=1, </math> this is equal to
:<math> \frac{1}{f(2)}f'(2)\cdot 2 =\frac{1}{3} (-5)\cdot 2 = -\frac{10}{3}. </math>
Hence, the slope of the tangent line at <math>x=1 </math> is equal to <math>-10/3. </math>
statement_html:
Find the slope of the graph of

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}y=\ln(f(2x))\end{aligned}\]

at \(x=1\), where \(f(2)=3\) and \(f'(2)=-5\).
statement_raw:
Find the slope of the graph of

:<math>
\displaystyle{}y=\ln(f(2x))
</math>

at <math>x=1</math>, where <math>f(2)=3</math> and <math>f'(2)=-5</math>.
